title: General election: EU citizens and 16-year-olds won't get a vote after bid fails
text:

EU citizens and 16-year-olds will not get a vote in the next UK general election after Labour's bid to extend rights to them failed in the House of Commons.

Two crucial amendments to Boris Johnson's early election Bill were not selected by the Deputy Speaker - meaning they could not be put to a vote.

It came after Boris Johnson threatened to pull the entire push for an election if they passed.

It means the first December election since 1923 now looks set to go ahead without extending the franchise to the young or more than 3million EU citizens in the UK.

MPs were, however, debating and vote on Labour's amendment that would change the proposed date of the election from December 12 to December 9.

Deputy Speaker Lindsay Hoyle took the decision on the advice of Commons clerks. It is thought both were ruled out of scope for the Early Parliamentary General Election Bill - which only had a very narrow remit.

(Image: REUTERS)

Labour prefer the earlier date for a number of reasons - chiefly that it wouldn't allow time for Boris Johnson to try and bounce Parliament into voting for his Brexit bill before it dissolves for the election.

Labour also say the later date risked disenfranchising students, because they will have broken up for Christmas by the 12th and wouldn't be able to vote in the constituencies where they live for most of the year.

(Image: SWNS.com)

Number 10 had indicated it was prepared to pull the election bill altogether if an amendment changing the franchise was attached.

The PM’s spokesman replied “yes” when asked if the Bill would be pulled if an amendment passed.

“If you vote for a change in the franchise, you are voting for a delay”, the PM’s spokesman said.

But Jeremy Corbyn said: "All 16-year-olds should have the right to vote.

"It seems to me fundamental to our democracy. It's young people's future after all that we will be debating in this election."

EU citizens living in the UK can register to vote, and can vote in European Parliament and local elections - but not general elections.

Likewise the Tories have repeatedly refused bids to extend the franchise to 16- and 17-year-olds, with the current voting age set firmly at 18.
description: Neither of the amendments were selected by the Speaker after Boris Johnson threatened to pull the entire push for an election if they passed
